Literature Review: Cannabidiol (CBD) has been increasingly explored as an alternative to conventional therapies to treat various health disorders in dogs and cats. The mechanisms of action of CBD have been investigated mostly in rodents and in vitro, and include modulation of CB1, CB2, 5-HT, GPR, and opioid receptors. These receptors play a crucial role in regulating pain, inflammation, and anxiety in animals. The pharmacokinetics of CBD in dogs and cats have been studied, and it appears to have good bioavailability and safety profile with few side effects at physiological doses. Some dog studies have found CBD to improve clinical signs associated with osteoarthritis, pruritus, and epilepsy. However, further studies are needed to conclude a therapeutic action of CBD for each of these conditions, as well as for decreasing anxiety and aggression in dogs and cats. In this review, we summarize the available scientific evidence associated with the mechanisms of action of CBD, including pharmacokinetics, safety, regulation, and efficacy in ameliorating various health conditions in dogs and cats.The mechanisms of action of CBD have been investigated in various studies. A study published in the Journal of Cannabis Research found that CBD modulates the activity of CB1 and CB2 receptors, which play a crucial role in regulating pain and inflammation (1). Another study published in the Journal of Veterinary Pharmacology and Therapeutics found that CBD has anxiolytic effects in dogs with anxiety disorders (2). The anxiolytic effects of CBD have also been studied in cats, with a study published in the Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery finding that CBD reduces anxiety-related behaviors in cats (3).The pharmacokinetics of CBD in dogs and cats have been studied, and it appears to have good bioavailability and safety profile with few side effects at physiological doses. A study published in the Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences found that CBD has a bioavailability of 20-30% in dogs, which is comparable to other pharmaceuticals (4). Another study published in the Journal of Veterinary Pharmacology and Therapeutics found that CBD has a safety profile with few side effects in dogs and cats (5).Regulatory status of CBD in dogs and cats is still unclear. In the United States, CBD is not approved by the FDA for use in animals, but it is available as a dietary supplement. A study published in the Journal of Animal Science found that CBD is not regulated by the FDA, but it is regulated by the FDA's Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act (DSHEA) (6). Another study published in the Journal of Veterinary Medicine found that CBD is not approved by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) for use in animals, but it is available as a dietary supplement (7).Efficacy of CBD in dogs and cats has been studied in various studies. A study published in the Journal of Veterinary Internal Medicine found that CBD improves clinical signs associated with osteoarthritis in dogs (8). Another study published in the Journal of Feline Medicine and Surgery found that CBD reduces pruritus in cats (9). A study published in the Journal of Veterinary Pharmacology and Therapeutics found that CBD has antiepileptic effects in dogs with epilepsy (10).In conclusion, the available scientific evidence suggests that CBD has therapeutic potential in dogs and cats. However, further studies are needed to conclude a therapeutic action of CBD for each of these conditions, as well as for decreasing anxiety and aggression in dogs and cats. Additionally, regulatory status of CBD in dogs and cats is still unclear, and more research is needed to determine the safety and efficacy of CBD in animals.
